span.span: Research Center for Information Science and Education, Hiroshima University

div.p: The studies of the quantum corrections for the anisotropy parameter, η(=ξR/ξB)annotated𝜂absentsubscript𝜉𝑅subscript𝜉𝐵italic-eta OPEN:( RELOP:equals italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\eta(=\xi_{R}/\xi_{B}), for the improved actions, β⁢(C0⁢L⁢(Plaq.)+C1⁢L⁢(Rect.))𝛽subscript𝐶0𝐿Plaq.subscript𝐶1𝐿Rect.italic-beta OPEN:( italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-L OPEN:( ATOM:Plaq. CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-L OPEN:( ATOM:Rect. CLOSE:) CLOSE:)\beta(C_{0}L(\mbox{Plaq.})+C_{1}L(\mbox{Rect.})), are proceeded in the medium to strong coupling region on anisotropic lattices. The global features for the η𝜂italic-eta\eta parameters as a function of β𝛽italic-beta\beta and the coefficient C1subscript𝐶1italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{1} have been clarified. It has been found by the perturbative analysis that as C1subscript𝐶1italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{1} decreases, the slope of the η⁢(β)𝜂𝛽italic-eta OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)\eta(\beta) becomes less steep and for the actions whose C1subscript𝐶1italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{1} is less than -0.1600.160ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.160-0.160, η𝜂italic-eta\eta decreases as β𝛽italic-beta\beta decreases, contrary to the case of the standard action. In the medium to strong coupling region, the η𝜂italic-eta\eta parameter begins to increase as β𝛽italic-beta\beta decreases for all C1subscript𝐶1italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{1}. This means that for the actions with C1<-0.160subscript𝐶10.160italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.160C_{1}<-0.160, the one-loop perturbative results for η𝜂italic-eta\eta break down qualitatively and the η𝜂italic-eta\eta parameters have a dip. As a result of this dip structure the η𝜂italic-eta\eta for Iwasaki’s action remains close to unity in the wide range of β𝛽italic-beta\beta, which means that quantum corrections for the anisotropy parameters are small for it.

The advantage of using improved actions has been recognized in many area of lattice simulations; at the same time the merits of using anisotropic lattice have been well understood[1]. Then we had started the study of the anisotropic properties for the improved actions[2]. The improved actions we study in this work consist of terms

semantics.annotation: italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu PUNCT:, italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-beta OPEN:( italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-L OPEN:( ATOM:Plaq. CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu PUNCT:, italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-L OPEN:( ATOM:Rect. CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu PUNCT:, italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)

div.p:
where L⁢(Plaq.)𝐿Plaq.italic-L OPEN:( ATOM:Plaq. CLOSE:)L(\mbox{Plaq.}) and L⁢(Rect.)𝐿Rect.italic-L OPEN:( ATOM:Rect. CLOSE:)L(\mbox{Rect.}) represent plaquette and 6-link rectangular loops respectively, and C0subscript𝐶0italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{0} and C1subscript𝐶1italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{1} satisfies C0+8⋅C1=1subscript𝐶0⋅8subscript𝐶11italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus NUMBER:8 MULOP:cdot italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1C_{0}+8\cdot C_{1}=1. Our improved action covers
i) tree level Symanzik’s action(C1=-1/12subscript𝐶1112italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:12C_{1}=-1/12)[3],
ii) Iwasaki’s action(C1=-0.331subscript𝐶10.331italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.331C_{1}=-0.331)[4],
iii) QCDTARO’s action(C1=-1.409subscript𝐶11.409italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1.409C_{1}=-1.409)[5]
etc.
For these classes of improved actions the anisotropic lattice is formulated in the same way as in the case of standard plaquette action[1]. We introduce the coupling constant, gσsubscript𝑔𝜎italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:endg_{\sigma}, (gτsubscript𝑔𝜏italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:endg_{\tau}) and lattice spacing, aσsubscript𝑎𝜎italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{\sigma}, (aτsubscript𝑎𝜏italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{\tau}) in space (temperature) direction. With these parameters, the action on the anisotropic lattice is written as,

semantics.annotation: italic-S RELOP:equals italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:cdot italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:cdot italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p:
where βσ=gσ-2⁢ξR-1subscript𝛽𝜎superscriptsubscript𝑔𝜎2superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑅1italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\beta_{\sigma}=g_{\sigma}^{-2}\xi_{R}^{-1}, βτ=gτ-2⁢ξRsubscript𝛽𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑔𝜏2subscript𝜉𝑅italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\beta_{\tau}=g_{\tau}^{-2}\xi_{R} and ξR=aσ/aτsubscript𝜉𝑅subscript𝑎𝜎subscript𝑎𝜏italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\xi_{R}=a_{\sigma}/a_{\tau}.
In the weak coupling expansions, the η𝜂italic-eta\eta parameter has been written as follows,

semantics.annotation: italic-eta RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-N MULOP:cdot italic-alpha OPEN:( italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) MULOP:divide italic-beta ADDOP:plus italic-O OPEN:( italic-g POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: The behavior of α⁢(ξR,C1)𝛼subscript𝜉𝑅subscript𝐶1italic-alpha OPEN:( italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\alpha(\xi_{R},C_{1}) had already been reported at lat98[2], which we will show in Fig.1.

figure.figcaption: Figure 1: The coefficients α𝛼italic-alpha\alpha as a function of C1subscript𝐶1italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{1}

div.p:
We have found that α⁢(ξR,C1)𝛼subscript𝜉𝑅subscript𝐶1italic-alpha OPEN:( italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\alpha(\xi_{R},C_{1}) changes sign around C1∼-0.160similar-tosubscript𝐶10.160italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.160C_{1}\sim-0.160. Namely in the weak coupling region, for the Iwasaki’s and QCDTARO’s actions, the η𝜂italic-eta\eta parameter is less than unity contrary to the case of the standard plaquette action.
The natural question is what is the behavior of η𝜂italic-eta\eta in the intermediate to weak coupling region, for those improved actions.

Numerically, the parameter η𝜂italic-eta\eta is calculated by the relation η=ξR/ξB𝜂subscript𝜉𝑅subscript𝜉𝐵italic-eta RELOP:equals italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\eta=\xi_{R}/\xi_{B}[6][7][8] , where ξBsubscript𝜉𝐵italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\xi_{B} is a bare anisotropy parameter which appears in the action,

semantics.annotation: italic-S RELOP:equals italic-beta OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i NUMBER:4 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) PUNCT:,

div.p: while the renormalized anisotropy parameter is defined by ξR=aσ/aτsubscript𝜉𝑅subscript𝑎𝜎subscript𝑎𝜏italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\xi_{R}=a_{\sigma}/a_{\tau}. For the probe of the scale for the space and temperature direction, we use the lattice potential in these directions. The lattice potential in temperature direction is defined by Wilson loops in space-temperature plane,

semantics.annotation: italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-p PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals OPFUNCTION:natural-logarithm OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-W POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-p PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start italic-W POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-p ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) ARG:end CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p:
The potential in the space direction is defined in a similar way.
The simulations are mainly done on the 123×24superscript12324NUMBER:12 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:times NUMBER:2412^{3}\times 24 lattice for ξR=2.0subscript𝜉𝑅2.0italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.0\xi_{R}=2.0, and for some β𝛽italic-beta\beta on 163×32superscript16332NUMBER:16 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:times NUMBER:3216^{3}\times 32 lattice to study the size dependences.
The method of determination of η𝜂italic-eta\eta is explained in some detail by the examples of β=4.5𝛽4.5italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:4.5\beta=4.5 for Iwasaki’s improved action.
We fix ξR=2subscript𝜉𝑅2italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2\xi_{R}=2, and calculate the rate

semantics.annotation: italic-R OPEN:( italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-p PUNCT:, italic-r CLOSE:) RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-p PUNCT:, italic-r CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-p PUNCT:, italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-t CLOSE:) ARG:end

div.p: at ξB=2.0,2.1,2,2subscript𝜉𝐵2.02.122italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2.1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2\xi_{B}=2.0,2.1,2,2. The results for ξB=2.1subscript𝜉𝐵2.1italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.1\xi_{B}=2.1 are shown in the Fig.2 for each p𝑝italic-pp and r𝑟italic-rr.

figure.figcaption: Figure 2: Ratio R⁢(p,r)𝑅𝑝𝑟italic-R OPEN:( italic-p PUNCT:, italic-r CLOSE:)R(p,r) for β=4.5𝛽4.5italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:4.5\beta=4.5 and ξB=2.1subscript𝜉𝐵2.1italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.1\xi_{B}=2.1

div.p: For these R⁢(ξB)𝑅subscript𝜉𝐵italic-R OPEN:( italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)R(\xi_{B}) we have made the interpolation by the second order polynomial in ξBsubscript𝜉𝐵italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\xi_{B} and solve the point where R=1𝑅1italic-R RELOP:equals NUMBER:1R=1 is satisfied. Then the η𝜂italic-eta\eta is obtained for each p𝑝italic-pp and r𝑟italic-rr. The results for the η𝜂italic-eta\eta are shown in Fig.3.

figure.figcaption: Figure 3: η⁢(p×r)𝜂𝑝𝑟italic-eta OPEN:( italic-p MULOP:times italic-r CLOSE:)\eta(p\times r) at β=4.5𝛽4.5italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:4.5\beta=4.5 and ξR=2.0subscript𝜉𝑅2.0italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.0\xi_{R}=2.0

div.p:
It is found that for p×r≥15𝑝𝑟15italic-p MULOP:times italic-r RELOP:greater-than-or-equals NUMBER:15p\times r\geq 15, η𝜂italic-eta\eta is almost flat. For the flat region, we take the average of them. The errors are estimated by the Jackknife method. The same analysis has been repeated for other β𝛽italic-beta\beta and for the other Improved actions.
In order to check the size dependences, the simulations are carried out on 163×32superscript16332NUMBER:16 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:times NUMBER:3216^{3}\times 32 lattice at β=21.0𝛽21.0italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:21.0\beta=21.0 and 3.53.5NUMBER:3.53.5 for the Iwasaki’s improved action. It is found that at β=21.0𝛽21.0italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:21.0\beta=21.0 the size dependence is not small but at β=3.5𝛽3.5italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:3.5\beta=3.5 it is quite small. Therefore for the intermediate to strong coupling region, the simulation is carried out on 123×24superscript12324NUMBER:12 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:times NUMBER:2412^{3}\times 24 lattice. All the results are summarized in Fig.4.

figure.figcaption: Figure 4: All the results for η⁢(β,C1)𝜂𝛽subscript𝐶1italic-eta OPEN:( italic-beta PUNCT:, italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\eta(\beta,C_{1}). The results for the standard action is from Ref.6

div.p:
∙∙MULOP:bullet\bullet Iwasaki’s Action
The η𝜂italic-eta\eta parameter has a shallow dip at β∼6.0similar-to𝛽6.0italic-beta RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:6.0\beta\sim 6.0 and then blows up towards the small β𝛽italic-beta\beta region. The prediction by the one loop perturbative calculation breaks down qualitatively. As a results of this behavior the η∼1similar-to𝜂1italic-eta RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1\eta\sim 1 in the wide range of β𝛽italic-beta\beta.
The results for ξR=3subscript𝜉𝑅3italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:3\xi_{R}=3 are also shown in the Fig.4. It is found that the qualitative behavior is the same but the dip around β=6.0𝛽6.0italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:6.0\beta=6.0 becomes deeper. This means that the renormalization of the anisotropy parameter is larger for larger ξRsubscript𝜉𝑅italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\xi_{R}.

∙∙MULOP:bullet\bullet Tree-level Symanzik’s Action and the action with C1=-0.16subscript𝐶10.16italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.16C_{1}=-0.16
The η𝜂italic-eta\eta for Symanzik’s action is qualitatively the same as those of the standard action[8]; namely it increases monotonically as β𝛽italic-beta\beta decreases. But the slope is less steep and then the value of η𝜂italic-eta\eta is smaller than the standard action at a given β𝛽italic-beta\beta.
For the action with C1=-0.16subscript𝐶10.16italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.16C_{1}=-0.16, it has been found that α=0𝛼0italic-alpha RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\alpha=0, namely the renormalization of the anisotropy parameter is zero in the weak coupling perturbative calculations[2]. The η𝜂italic-eta\eta in the intermediate to strong coupling region shows similar behavior with the standard plaquette action and Symanzik’s action. But again the slope becomes less steep.

∙∙MULOP:bullet\bullet Global features of η⁢(β,C1)𝜂𝛽subscript𝐶1italic-eta OPEN:( italic-beta PUNCT:, italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\eta(\beta,C_{1})
The calculation with the QCDTARO’s action is not carried out yet. But we have found the global structure of the η𝜂italic-eta\eta parameter as a function of β𝛽italic-beta\beta and C1subscript𝐶1italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{1}. The interesting point is that the for the action with C1<-0.16subscript𝐶10.16italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.16C_{1}<-0.16, the η𝜂italic-eta\eta once decreases and then increases with decreasing β𝛽italic-beta\beta. As a result of this behavior the η𝜂italic-eta\eta stays close to one in the wide range of β𝛽italic-beta\beta for Iwasaki’s improved action. This may be a good features for the numerical simulations.

∙∙MULOP:bullet\bullet Further works
The calculation of the η𝜂italic-eta\eta at stronger coupling region and the other ξR=0.5,1.5,3.05.0subscript𝜉𝑅0.51.53.05.0italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.5 PUNCT:, NUMBER:1.5 PUNCT:, NUMBER:3.05.0\xi_{R}=0.5,1.5,3.05.0 etc are now under study. We are preparing to use the smeared Wilson loops for the simulation in the stronger coupling region.
We are starting the calculation of the lattice spacing a𝑎italic-aa as a function of β𝛽italic-beta\beta on the anisotropic lattices.
The behavior of η𝜂italic-eta\eta with smaller C1subscript𝐶1italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{1} like QCDTARO’s action, is also an interesting problem.
We are preparing the simulations of physical quantities on an anisotropic lattice with improved actions. The targets are heavy quark spectroscopy, transport coefficients of quark gluon plasma etc.

ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
The present work has been done with SX-4 at RCNP and VX-4 at Yamagata. We are grateful for the members of RCNP for warm hospitality and kind supports.

li.span: S.Sakai, A.Nakamura and T.Saito, Nucl. Phys. B(Proc Suppl)73(1999), 417
Y. Iwasaki, Nucl. Phys. B258(1985), 141; Univ. of Tsukuba preprint UTHEP-118(1983)
QCD-TARO Collaboration, Ph. de Forcrand et al. hep-lat/9806008
G.Burgers et al., Nucl. Phys. B204, 587, 1988
J.Engels, F.Karsch and T. Scheideler hep-lat/9905002
